segments.text: I felt were the most important at that time that I had something to do with was, first was the Academy's Committee on Oceanography, which was either its second or third committee on oceanography, I forgot which.
This again was a brainchild, I think, of Gordon's and Gordon, Lil, and myself.
We'd been putting together a
program in the Navy, a long-range program.
And we thought there ought to be a little broader look at this, that this should be done on a national basis.
And we thought it would be appropriate to have an Academy Committee on Oceanography.
So I went over and talked to John Coleman, who was executive officer of the Academy at that time.
And I guess Bronk was president of the Academy.
And Bronk agreed to it.
And the question was who to get as chairman.
And John Coleman picked up the phone and called Harrison Brown and asked him if he'd agree to be chairman.
And he did.
And I've forgotten who was on the original committee, but it was people like
Columbus Islin and Roger Revelle, Morris Ewing, Sumner Pike, Harrison Brown.
I'm sure there's a list of these around.
Dick Better would know it.
And when it was established, they invited Dick to be its executive secretary.
And he's been there ever since.
And that has to be close to 20 years now.
So it's been going a very long time.
And that committee sat down and spent many months of deliberations.
And although I was not a member, I sat in on virtually every meeting as government representative.
And they put together a thick report on oceanography.
I think it was called Oceanography 1960 to 1970 or something like that.
And it had a major impact on the whole business.
I think it was the guiding thing.
I like to think that what we had done in the Navy had an impact also.
We put together a program called 10OC, or 10 Years in Oceanography, for the Navy, which had a long range projection of growth in oceanography, new ships, and so on in the business.
And the Navy stuck to this pretty well.
for most of the 10 years.
It essentially became a part of the Academy's committee.
I think it was about this time that the administration or the bureaucracy began to grow significantly in oceanography.
One of the things
that we found was becoming necessary was that oceanography was being done not only in ONR, but in many agencies of the government.
And there was a need to coordinate this.
So we began getting a group together that was called the Interagency Committee on Oceanography, I believe, ICO.
At first, people got together on the working level and just tried to plan programs, coordinate things, and so forth.
And it began to grow, and we began to get the heads of agencies interested in this.
And I remember the first day that Jim Wakeland came on board as Assistant Secretary of the Navy for R&D.
I went and spent something like six hours with him and told him all about oceanography, what the Navy was doing in it, and the fact that we'd set up this interagency committee.
We wanted him to chair it and so on.
He immediately became interested in this, and we became pretty good friends.
I think it was about three weeks after that date,
Eisenhower asked him to brief the cabinet on oceanography.
So he got me to go along with him.
And it was quite an interesting day.
Again, Jim hadn't been in the Navy very long, so he didn't know much about it.
But we had a briefing all prepared.
And I sort of went along to answer questions if some came up that he couldn't field.
And I remember to this day when Eisenhower walked into the cabinet meeting
looked down the agenda and he says, oh, I see we have oceanography on the agenda today.
He says, where's Morris Ewing?
I said, Morris is up in Columbia where he belongs.
He sort of chuckled.
It was an interesting experience to go through that.
Was Eisenhower sympathetic?
Yes, he was.
Not much came out.
It was more of an information type briefing,
You know, oceanography was then becoming a word that people were hearing about and wondering what the hell it meant.
So they just wanted to find out what was included and what the country was doing.
And it didn't hurt us to go there, that's for sure.
But again, we were on that pretty steep part of the budget curve or science going up in interest at that time.
So you didn't have to justify things too much.
Were you in that famous meeting where Spiro Agnew said, what I'm really interested in is space, and left?
No.

That was the meeting of the, when they set up, I forgot what it's called now, the council, I guess, that had the heads of all the departments and the vice president chaired, and I suspect that was when he walked into that meeting.
Humphrey, who preceded him, was very sympathetic to oceanography.
And as you know, he was up here and went out to sea with us for a couple of days.
Very bright, interested guy.
He just followed everything very closely.
I don't know what other committees that were going at that time.
Oh, one of the subcommittees of the ICO that I got interested in was...
was called PIPICO, or at that time was the Panel on International Participation of the ICO.
And this group actually was the group of agencies that got together and provided the general government position on international meetings, and it's still doing it to this day.
consultant on it, and I get their material on a fairly regular basis.
And I'm still very active in this.
And this came about because a meeting that Roger and Roger Lavelle, John Lyman, and I went to with UNESCO many years ago decided that they'd set up a committee on oceanography.
We went to a
preparatory meeting in Copenhagen, as I recall.
And I couldn't tell you the dates on that now.
It must have been in the late 50s.
As a result of that meeting, they set up IOC, the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission, under UNESCO.
I was very active in that for many years.
And for many years, it was a fairly active organization that was promoting good science and the interchange of information between science.

But as the law of the sea began to raise its ugly head, it become more and more involved in nationalistic types of things, and the law of the sea, and spent more of its time trying to reorganize itself than thinking about oceanography.
became disillusioned with it and stopped going to it.
But the ICO now, or PIPICO, which is part of ICO in our government, was the U.S. input into that, even at that stage.
It still maintains its input.
I know this is a rather dumb question, but

In terms of law of the sea, do you intend to make overtures to underdeveloped countries and maybe bring them in here to Woods Hole or bring oceanographers so that you can establish the sort of contacts that will allow you to do joint oceanography off of, let's say, places like Chile or Brazil?
Oh, actually, that's undoubtedly yes.
We've done that through our whole history long before the law of the sea was a problem.
We've worked with
scientists from other countries and have developed quite close relationships, not only developing countries, but developed countries.
And we have a number of people that come spend some time here and then go back and vice versa.
Our people go over there.
We're particularly interested in developing countries and trying to help them get started.

Of course, we realize one of the side benefits on this is if you get to know the people, the chances of working off their shores with them is much simpler if you have somebody to go to that you know there.
But that's been a mode of operation that we've had for many years.
I see it coming to being more important in the future.
I think the law of the sea is really going to finish down to
that may be the only way of doing research.
Obviously, I know you're not a mystic, but did you anticipate the Law of the Sea occurring while you were at ONR working with UNESCO?
Did you have hints that something like this was going to occur?
Oh, there was another Law of the Sea conference, as you recall, in 1959, I think, which they signed the famous treaty that set the limits of the 200-meter limit in this
far beyond that that admits to exploitation, as I recall, some language similar to this.

And the people that were involved in that, and that was Don McKernan and Benny Schaefer, Wib Chapman, and so on, were both pushing for a law of the sea and afraid, another law of the sea conference, and afraid that
Another one would occur.
There was a great question in everybody's mind as to timing on when you should have this.
And then it got somewhat taken out of people's hands by Pardo's statement at the UN saying that seabed is a property of mankind.
And it stirred up a lot of interest.
quite independent of what the scientists wanted to do about bringing about a law of the sea conference.
It got started in UN, and you couldn't stop it if you tried.
I'm not sure you're ever going to stop it or it's ever going to get solved.
I mean, it's going.
While we're talking about the Illinois, there's a very important point I want you to make some comments on.
Instrumentation and the development of ocean arms.
My impression is that few agencies contribute quite so much to the development and sophistication of instruments for oceanography as does ONR.
Tell me how you went about that.
How did you decide to fund new instruments?
What sort of proposals did you receive?
What kind of people did you try to deal with?
Problems you tried to solve?
Well, I think
The proposals at that time were not nearly as elaborate as they are now.
And I think the reason in part for that is that there were a lot of new ideas.
A lot of new technology was emerging.
And it was much easier to identify some of these.
I suspect ONR has supported a lot of technology and a lot of development technology.
It seems to me that it's hand in glove with doing science so that you don't do it for its own sake.
Although I know of a few projects that we undertook that some of them I've never been particularly happy with.
But we did undertake them in its technological developments.

Again, I think this sort of refers back to an earlier point you made, that the decision as to whether you wanted to invest some of your money into equipment or not rested with the people that were running things.
And they felt it made more sense to put some money to develop equipment that would be used by a broad group of people.
It went that way.
And it went that way not because any group proposed it, but there was a general feeling among the whole community that we needed this kind of equipment.
But the people didn't get together and put in a single proposal.
The feeling was there, so ONR took the bit in the teeth, set up a group, and went out and would run a program like that and get it going.
Now, I'm sure you're aware that...
It was ONR that got the deep-sea drilling the Glomar Challenger off.
Again, this was a little group in our group there.
We had a group in ONR called the American Miscellaneous Society, which started in our branch in ONR.
And I'm sure you've heard the story of the famous wine breakfast at Walter Monk's.
Well, there were a number of us out at Walter Monk's house.
Again, it's hard to put the date on this.
But we were discussing what are the new things that need to be done in oceanography.
And I remember Gordon Lill was there and myself.
I think Betty Bowden from Scripps was there and Walter.
The whole idea of the fact that the technology had reached a point in two places.
One, that onshore you could drill to great depths.
They had just drilled a well to about 30,000 feet in Texas.
And they were just beginning to come out with drilling platforms to drill at sea.
So there was a possibility of marrying these two technologies, one deep drilling and drilling at sea.
that maybe you could drill to 30,000 feet at sea.
And if you could do that, there were all sorts of interesting scientific problems that you could come into.
So as a result of this, the American Miscellaneous Society decided to put in a proposal to NSF to support this.
And it got supported for a committee to study it.
And I guess finally got to be an AMSOC committee of the National Academy of Sciences
for a while that, again, a lot of these same characters keep coming up.
Bill Bascom was head of this group, and they developed plans for the Moho.
Now, somewhere along the line in developing the Moho, a lot of divergent views came out.
There was one group of people that felt very strongly the way to proceed was to
to build a small ship and do some sediment drilling, and gradually build bigger and bigger ships.
And as you got better, go to deeper depths.
There was another group that felt that the way to do it was to start out with the platform that could do the final job, but started drilling on shallower depths.
But you had the platform which you were improving all the time.
Harry Hess of Princeton sort of headed the latter group, and Hollis Hedberg also of Princeton headed the former group.
And Walter Monk was inwell, I'm not sure which group Walter Monk was in.
I think he was in the one that preferred going with the smaller ones bigger.
But Moho decided to go the other way, and that was the side that I happened to be on in that.
got to the point where they let a contract for construction of the platform in San Diego.
Then the other end of it ran into trouble.
The Science Foundation was letting this out for contract, and they had several bids on it.
And as you recall, Lyndon Johnson was president at the time and was from Texas, and there was a couple of powerful congressmen from Texas.
And for one reason or another, the contract
ended up in Texas with Brown and Root.
This got Gordon Allen of Colorado very unhappy.
Apparently one of the other bidders was from his state, and so he raised a fuss on this, and eventually they canceled.
And a lot of things were happening.
The cost was escalating.
The cost had gotten up
estimated cost of about $100 million, I think, about that time.
There was a lot of discussion about the propriety of the way the contract was handled.
There was division in the scientific community on it.
And as a result, the whole thing collapsed.
But a lot came out of it, because the ocean sediment coring program, people agreed that the idea made a lot of sense.
So it sort of backed off.
The ocean sediment coring with the Glomar Challenger came out of that.
On the other end, all the design work that went into it are the things that these semi-submersible platforms were based on, so the technology was utilized by industry on it, and I think
None of the money was really wasted on it.
It really spurred on the oil industry.
Now the oil industry is putting just so much more money into that than the government ever would.
But this was kind of a thing that helped get it all started at the beginning.
But that whole program started with ONR funding the early stages of it.
I remember one meeting we had on this that

John Mecham, the oil man who had, I think, drilled, his company had drilled a hole to 30,000 feet, came up to Washington, and we were out at Bill Ruby's house, who was in the geological survey in Washington.
We had a fairly large meeting out there, 15 or 20 people, but there were some interesting people there, and apparently the FBI had had the whole house under surveillance that night.
for which nobody ever found out a reason why.
That was one of the, you know, these are kind of examples of the exciting kind of things that O&R was into at the time.
You could do a lot of things like this, and these were big step forwards in the business that they were making.
They were gambles.
But the people were willing to take it and were willing to put their reputations at stake on these.
And I think everybody plays the game much safer now.
I want to jump ahead of the story a little bit, and I want to drop back.
But if you were to list what you thought to be the technology, the instrumentation side of technology, which you developed the most in your career as oceanographer, what would you choose?
During my whole career During your whole career, what instruments were developed which you think brought the most to the science of oceanography?
Well, that's a tough one.
I think one couldn't help but say the computer.
That wasn't developed for the oceanographer or by the oceanographer, but that's been probably the biggest tool he's used, because everybody uses it in one form or another.
I think the current meters and the arrays of current meters that have been developed here have been a very significant part in understanding the oceans.
I think seismology has made some big changes.
Let me say one thing about the geophysical measurements at sea.
Some of these had never been made at sea before, and people like Morris Ewing and Morris Ewing started seismic measurements at sea.
I think that Scripps started the
magnetic measurements, Warzel gravity measurements, and Bullard and I, the heat flow.
When these were first made, they were very difficult to make.
But as soon as you began making them, you found out they were much easier to make in the ocean than on land.
And very rapidly, you develop more information about the ocean floor than you have about the land.
And since the geology of the ocean floor is simpler than the geology of the land masses,
We've been able to understand the geology of the Earth primarily because you've developed all of these geophysical tools that you can use at sea.
And this has probably been the most significant thing that has happened in oceanography during my history, is what we've learned about the sea floor, plate tectonics, sea floor spreading, and so on.

And it's come about from the simple fact that geophysical measurements, once you learn to make them at sea, you can get them in vast quantities very fast thereafter, and you get a much better picture of it.
And I think all the technology that's gone into those has been tremendously important.
Now, the second question actually relates to that.
You've led into it in a different way.
I need for you to say a few words about you and Bullard's work in the heat wave flow, because that's very important to the history of oceanography.
How did you get interested in it?
What do you think its significance was?
How did you intellectually develop it?
What problems did you face?
Well, I got interested in it very simply.
As I mentioned earlier, I by chance happened at Scripps the same time as Teddy Bullard had come to spend a year there to work on heat flow.
I knew nothing about it prior to that time.
What had happened is that there had been something of the order of two dozen measurements of heat flow that had been made at
on land, particularly in mines and in boreholes, where they measured the temperature at different depths and calculated the heat flowing out of the earth.
But that only represented kind of a small fraction of the whole earth.
And you had 2 thirds of it the oceans that there were no measurements for.
So it was critical to see what the heat flow was in the oceans.
The main driving force behind this is that we knew that the continental rocks were more acidic and they contained rocks that had higher contents of potassium and radioactivity in them.
And it was generally felt that the heat that was flowing from the earth was generated primarily by the decay of radioactive material in the crust of the earth about 30 kilometers.
And the rest was from the
original cooling of the earth.

Now, we knew under the oceans that the crust was thinner, and we knew that the material had less contact with radioactivity, so we anticipated that the heat flow would be smaller under the ocean, but we wanted to really find this out.
And in 1950, when we got our first measurements, it turned out it wasn't so.
All the early measurements showed that we were getting
roughly the same heat flow in the ocean floor as was measured in the continents.
An interesting thing about the early heat flow measurements was that on the Capricorn expedition that I went on, we picked up a pattern of heat flow that showed normal values in most areas.
But as you approached a ridge, you found that the heat flow was very high on the ridge.
three to four times the normal heat flow.
And then as you went off the ridge, it went back to normal, and then it went a little below normal and then back to the normal values.
And this pattern was found in the very earliest measurements of something like 30 measurements that were made, and now there's something like 3,000 measurements, which is
just borne out this pattern.
Of course, we found a lot of different things, but the main pattern of heat flow was found by the very early measurements, actually.
In my early work, we were thinking there were convection cells under the ocean floor.
Dave Griggs at UCLA and other people had thought in terms of convection cells.
And when we detected this high heat flow over the East Pacific rise, we thought that this was an upwelling of heat coming up from a convection cell.
And I actually postulated maybe it was the way continents were formed, that you had this material come up, and it gradually built a lot of it up, and it made a new continent.
which of course was not correct, but the whole idea of it being on a convection cell has turned out to be true.
The convection cell just goes all the way over to the edges.

As a matter of fact, on our early measurements, we made measurements of the heat flow between the East Pacific rise and South America there, and we got high heat flows on the rise, and they went down low to very low under the trench, which is the pattern that you would expect from a convection cell.
I think this has been one of the key parts in coming up with the whole study on plate tectonics.
It's not the whole thing, or it's not a critical one, but it's that compared with the magnetics, the seismic, the gravity.

It's when you put the whole works together, the picture began to emerge, and I know a lot of people have tried to set a date when plate tectonics was born or seafloor spreading, and I think that's probably not a
It's a thing that has evolved over many years, and a lot of measurements.
It was just putting a lot of pieces together, and finally somebody got a key piece in, and you could see the picture on it.
But it was a lot of work of a lot of people that developed that.
And I like to think that the heat flow was one of the important factors in it.
At least it was the first heat flow at sea, in any case.
And I think it was significant.
